statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: The Portland Trail Blazers encouraged Damon Stoudamire to keep shooting down the stretch. Stoudamire shot 4-for-5 from the field and scored 14 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter as the Trail Blazers rallied to beat the Miami Heat 92-85 Thursday night.
article.headline: Heat held to 30 second-half points
article.linkText: Stoudamire, Blazers rally to beat the Heat
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- The Portland Trail Blazers encouraged Damon Stoudamire to keep shooting down the stretch.
Stoudamire

Stoudamire shot 4-for-5 from the field and scored 14 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter as the Trail Blazers rallied to beat the Miami Heat 92-85 Thursday night. "My teammates told me after I made a couple of shots to not even think about passing the ball," said Stoudamire, 4-for-5 from the field in the final quarter with two 3-pointers. "They wanted me to keep shooting it." Rasheed Wallace and Bonzi Wells each scored 23 points for the Trail Blazers, who overcame a 17-point deficit despite shooting just 39 percent from the floor. "We dug down deep and got one that we didn't think we could get," Stoudamire said. "We started to pressure them up the floor. They had to settle for a lot of jumpers. Not too many teams are going to beat you doing that." Stoudamire gave Portland its first lead at 76-75 on a driving layup with 4:06 remaining. He scored Portland's last seven points, including a 3-pointer that pushed the Trail Blazers' lead to 86-79. "He just made the shots," Portland coach Maurice Cheeks said. "He played very big for us tonight. He played 40 minutes and we needed every bit of it." Eddie Jones scored 25 points for the Heat, including 19 in the first half. Alonzo Mourning added 16 points, Rod Strickland 13 points and Brian Grant 10. "Somebody else has got to do something too," Heat coach Pat Riley said. "He (Jones) has been carrying us for the last week." Riley said Jimmy Jackson and LaPhonso Ellis need to produce more. Both players finished with six points. Miami, which led 55-44 at halftime, scored just 30 points in the second half and was outscored 27-14 in the fourth quarter. "It was like two entirely different games," Riley said. "We showed a tremendous amount of confidence, energy, will and a real purpose in the first half. And then in the second half, we begin to lose our confidence." The Heat shot 61 percent in the first half and shot 46 percent from the field for the game. In the fourth quarter, Miami went 6:01 without scoring a point. Mourning hit a short jumper to give Miami a 61-48 lead in the third quarter. Portland countered with a 9-0 run and used a 15-6 outburst to close within 67-63. "Mistake after mistake and you lose the game," Mourning said. "It's that simple. It was our mistakes, not their defense." Miami committed eight turnovers in the quarter. The Trail Blazers scored 22 points off 19 turnovers. "We figured they couldn't keep shooting at a 60-percent pace," Wells said. "Damon can score. He's a point guard, but he can shoot. We told him to keep putting it up. When he does that, he takes pressure off everyone else." Miami made 13 of its first 15 shots and pushed its early lead to 30-16 on a layup by Mourning. "One thing I've learned about this game is to keep playing and eventually good things are going to happen," Stoudamire said. "This is a big victory. One we haven't had in a while, especially on the road." Game notes
Portland's Dale Davis remained in Atlanta, where the Trail Blazers played Tuesday, because of undisclosed family reasons. Davis is expected to rejoin the team Friday in Orlando. ... Chris Dudley made his first start of the season. ... Jackson became the 233rd player in NBA history to surpass the 10,000-point mark. He scored six points on Thursday, raising his career total to 10,003. ... Kendall Gill left the game in the first half with flu-like symptoms. ... Portland, in the midst of a four-game road trip, is 6-12 away from home. ... The Heat, 14-for-20 in the first quarter, matched a season-best shooting percentage for a quarter. ... Anthony Carter, on the injured list since Dec. 21 with a lower abdominal muscle problem, underwent surgery Thursday to repair a sports hernia. His status will be determined in two weeks.
